     1‚Üí# PROJECT CONTEXT ‚Äî Capstone Quality Pipeline Handoff
     2‚Üí## For Claude / future assistants working on this repo
     3‚Üí
     4‚ÜíDmitrii‚Äôs intent (capstone): build real muscle in **Red Teaming**, **Evaluations**, and **AI Product Lifecycle** by turning a fast-grown ‚Äúvibecoded‚Äù portfolio project into a **repeatable, auditable system**.
     5‚Üí
     6‚ÜíThis handoff summarizes what was added/changed so you can continue without having the chat history.
     7‚Üí
     8‚Üí---
     9‚Üí
    10‚Üí## What was built (high-level)
    11‚Üí
    12‚ÜíThis repo already had:
    13‚Üí- a portfolio site (Vite + React)
    14‚Üí- structured content in `content/`
    15‚Üí- a ‚ÄúUniversal CV‚Äù concept: generate **variants** tailored to a job
    16‚Üí
    17‚ÜíThe capstone upgrade is: **make quality checks executable**.
    18‚Üí
    19‚ÜíWe implemented:
    20‚Üí
    21‚Üí1) **Variants coherence**: YAML is canonical, JSON is runtime  
    22‚Üí2) **Executable evaluation**: ‚Äúclaims ledger‚Äù that makes factual traceability machine-checkable  
    23‚Üí3) **Executable red team**: repeatable scan + report per variant
    24‚Üí
    25‚Üí---
    26‚Üí
    27‚Üí## The architecture (mental model)
    28‚Üí
    29‚Üí### Artifact flow (canonical ‚Üí runtime)
    30‚Üí
    31‚Üí- **Canonical (human/agent edits):** `content/variants/<slug>.yaml`
    32‚Üí- **Runtime (site loads):** `content/variants/<slug>.json`
    33‚Üí
    34‚ÜíThe site loads JSON via Vite glob import:
    35‚Üí
    36‚Üí- `src/lib/variants.ts` uses `import.meta.glob('../../content/variants/*.json')`
    37‚Üí
    38‚ÜíSo JSON must exist and must match YAML.
    39‚Üí
    40‚Üí### Quality pipeline (capstone)
    41‚Üí
    42‚Üí```
    43‚ÜíTruth (content/knowledge/**)
    44‚Üí   ‚Üì
    45‚ÜíVariant (content/variants/*.yaml)
    46‚Üí   ‚Üì  variants:sync
    47‚ÜíRuntime artifact (content/variants/*.json)
    48‚Üí   ‚Üì  eval:variant
    49‚ÜíClaims ledger (capstone/develop/evals/*.claims.yaml)
    50‚Üí   ‚Üì  redteam:variant
    51‚ÜíRed team report (capstone/develop/redteam/*.redteam.md)
    52‚Üí   ‚Üì
    53‚ÜíShip (deploy)
    54‚Üí```
    55‚Üí
    56‚Üí---
    57‚Üí
    58‚Üí## Code added (scripts)
    59‚Üí
    60‚Üí### 1) Variant sync
    61‚Üí**File:** `scripts/sync-variants.ts`  
    62‚Üí**Purpose:** generate deterministic JSON from YAML; detect drift
    63‚Üí
    64‚ÜíCommands:
    65‚Üí- `npm run variants:sync`
    66‚Üí- `npm run variants:check`
    67‚Üí
    68‚Üí### 2) Executable evaluation
    69‚Üí**File:** `scripts/evaluate-variants.ts`  
    70‚Üí**Purpose:**
    71‚Üí- extract **metric-like claims** from variant overrides
    72‚Üí- suggest candidate sources from `content/knowledge/**`
    73‚Üí- write a claims ledger + human checklist
    74‚Üí- enforce machine-checkable gates
    75‚Üí
    76‚ÜíCommands:
    77‚Üí- `npm run eval:variant -- --slug <slug>`
    78‚Üí- `npm run eval:all`
    79‚Üí- `npm run eval:check`
    80‚Üí
    81‚ÜíArtifacts:
    82‚Üí- `capstone/develop/evals/<slug>.claims.yaml`
    83‚Üí- `capstone/develop/evals/<slug>.eval.md`
    84‚Üí
    85‚ÜíWrite-back helper (optional):
    86‚Üí- `npm run eval:variant -- --slug <slug> --verify <claimId>=<sourcePath>`
    87‚Üí
    88‚Üí### 3) Executable red team
    89‚Üí**File:** `scripts/redteam.ts`  
    90‚Üí**Purpose:** scan variant content for portfolio-relevant risks
    91‚Üí
    92‚ÜíCommands:
    93‚Üí- `npm run redteam:variant -- --slug <slug>`
    94‚Üí- `npm run redteam:all`
    95‚Üí- `npm run redteam:check`
    96‚Üí- `npm run redteam:check -- --strict`
    97‚Üí
    98‚ÜíArtifact:
    99‚Üí- `capstone/develop/redteam/<slug>.redteam.md`
   100‚Üí
   101‚Üí---
   102‚Üí
   103‚Üí## Key bug fix
   104‚Üí
   105‚Üí**File:** `src/lib/variants.ts`  
   106‚Üí**Fix:** `getVariantSlugs()` was incorrectly matching `*.yaml` even though variants are loaded from `*.json`. It now matches `*.json`.
   107‚Üí
   108‚Üí---
   109‚Üí
   110‚Üí## Small safety upgrade in generator
   111‚Üí
   112‚Üí**File:** `scripts/generate-cv.ts`
   113‚Üí
   114‚ÜíChanges:
   115‚Üí- job description in the prompt is now labeled **UNTRUSTED INPUT** and wrapped in `<JOB_DESCRIPTION>...</JOB_DESCRIPTION>` (prompt-injection hygiene)
   116‚Üí- printed URLs now correctly use HashRouter: `/#/company/role`
   117‚Üí- it reminds to run `npm run variants:sync`
   118‚Üí
   119‚Üí---
   120‚Üí
   121‚Üí## Capstone docs added/updated
   122‚Üí
   123‚ÜíNew:
   124‚Üí- `capstone/develop/executable-quality-pipeline.md`
   125‚Üí- `capstone/develop/evals/README.md`
   126‚Üí- `capstone/develop/redteam/README.md`
   127‚Üí
   128‚ÜíUpdated:
   129‚Üí- `capstone/develop/evaluation.md` now references the CLI
   130‚Üí- `capstone/develop/red-teaming.md` now references the CLI
   131‚Üí
   132‚Üí---
   133‚Üí
   134‚Üí## package.json changes (new commands)
   135‚Üí
   136‚ÜíAdded scripts:
   137‚Üí- `predev`: `npm run variants:sync`
   138‚Üí- `prebuild`: `npm run validate && npm run variants:sync`
   139‚Üí- `variants:*`, `eval:*`, `redteam:*`
   140‚Üí
   141‚Üí---
   142‚Üí
   143‚Üí## Mentor notes for Dmitrii (what to internalize)
   144‚Üí
   145‚Üí### 1) Treat ‚Äúevaluation‚Äù as a product behavior
   146‚ÜíNot a doc. Not vibes. A behavior you can rerun and gate.
   147‚Üí
   148‚ÜíThe claims ledger is the key muscle:
   149‚Üí- extract claims
   150‚Üí- verify against sources
   151‚Üí- anchors make it regression-proof
   152‚Üí
   153‚Üí### 2) Know your trust boundaries
   154‚Üí- Knowledge base = trusted (facts)
   155‚Üí- Job descriptions = untrusted (can contain prompt injection or nonsense)
   156‚Üí- Variant output is publishable, so it must be defensible
   157‚Üí
   158‚Üí### 3) Don‚Äôt fix facts in the output
   159‚ÜíIf you catch a mismatch:
   160‚Üí- fix the source of truth (knowledge files) OR remove the claim
   161‚Üí- then regenerate / re-evaluate
   162‚Üí
   163‚Üí### 4) Keep scope tight
   164‚ÜíThis capstone is about:
   165‚Üí- evals
   166‚Üí- red teaming
   167‚Üí- lifecycle gates
   168‚Üí
   169‚ÜíNot about building a full agent platform.
   170‚Üí
   171‚Üí---
   172‚Üí
   173‚Üí## Suggested next moves (if continuing)
   174‚Üí
   175‚Üí1) Run `npm run eval:all`
   176‚Üí2) Pick one variant and verify **every claim** in its ledger
   177‚Üí3) Run `npm run redteam:variant -- --slug <slug>`
   178‚Üí4) Only then consider CI gating (optional): `eval:check` + `redteam:check`
   179‚Üí
   180‚Üí

     1‚Üí# Content Management Guide
     2‚Üí
     3‚ÜíComplete guide for managing content in the portfolio.
     4‚Üí
     5‚Üí## Overview
     6‚Üí
     7‚ÜíThe portfolio uses a **file-based content system** with:
     8‚Üí- ‚úÖ **Auto-discovery** - Drop files and they appear
     9‚Üí- ‚úÖ **Type safety** - Zod validation catches errors
    10‚Üí- ‚úÖ **Hot reload** - See changes instantly in development
    11‚Üí- ‚úÖ **Templates** - Copy-paste starter files
    12‚Üí
    13‚Üí## Content Types
    14‚Üí
    15‚Üí| Type | Location | Format | Auto-discovered |
    16‚Üí|------|----------|--------|-----------------|
    17‚Üí| Case Studies | `content/case-studies/` | Markdown + YAML | Yes |
    18‚Üí| Passion Projects | `content/passion-projects/index.yaml` | YAML array | No |
    19‚Üí| Blog Posts | `content/blog/` | Markdown + YAML | Yes |
    20‚Üí| Profile | `content/profile.yaml` | YAML | No |
    21‚Üí| Experience | `content/experience/index.yaml` | YAML | No |
    22‚Üí| Testimonials | `content/testimonials/index.yaml` | YAML | No |
    23‚Üí| Certifications | `content/certifications/index.yaml` | YAML | No |
    24‚Üí
    25‚Üí---
    26‚Üí
    27‚Üí## Adding New Content
    28‚Üí
    29‚Üí### Case Study
    30‚Üí
    31‚Üí1. **Copy template:**
    32‚Üí```bash
    33‚Üícp content/_templates/case-study.md content/case-studies/05-my-project.md
    34‚Üí```
    35‚Üí
    36‚Üí2. **Edit frontmatter:**
    37‚Üí   - Update `id` (next available: 5, 6, 7...)
    38‚Üí   - Set unique `slug`
    39‚Üí   - Fill all required fields
    40‚Üí   - Remove optional fields you don't need
    41‚Üí
    42‚Üí3. **Write content:**
    43‚Üí   - Use markdown below the `---` delimiter
    44‚Üí   - Follow existing structure
    45‚Üí   - Include metrics, decisions, learnings
    46‚Üí
    47‚Üí4. **Validate:**
    48‚Üí```bash
    49‚Üínpm run validate
    50‚Üí```
    51‚Üí
    52‚Üí5. **Preview:**
    53‚Üí```bash
    54‚Üínpm run dev
    55‚Üí# Visit http://localhost:5173
    56‚Üí```
    57‚Üí
    58‚Üí**File naming:** `NN-slug.md` where NN is the ID padded with zeros
    59‚Üí
    60‚Üí---
    61‚Üí
    62‚Üí### Passion Project
    63‚Üí
    64‚Üí1. **Copy template entry:**
    65‚Üí```bash
    66‚Üícat content/_templates/passion-project-entry.yaml
    67‚Üí```
    68‚Üí
    69‚Üí2. **Edit `content/passion-projects/index.yaml`:**
    70‚Üí   - Add new entry to `projects` array
    71‚Üí   - Update `id` (next number in sequence)
    72‚Üí   - Fill required fields
    73‚Üí   - Set URLs to `null` if not applicable
    74‚Üí
    75‚Üí3. **Validate:**
    76‚Üí```bash
    77‚Üínpm run validate
    78‚Üí```
    79‚Üí
    80‚Üí**Example:**
    81‚Üí```yaml
    82‚Üíprojects:
    83‚Üí  # ... existing projects
    84‚Üí  - id: 10
    85‚Üí    slug: my-new-project
    86‚Üí    title: My Project
    87‚Üí    tagline: What it does in one line
    88‚Üí    year: "2024"
    89‚Üí    tags: [CLI, Tools]
    90‚Üí    thumbnail: null
    91‚Üí    githubUrl: https://github.com/user/repo
    92‚Üí    liveUrl: null
    93‚Üí    docsUrl: null
    94‚Üí```
    95‚Üí
    96‚Üí---
    97‚Üí
    98‚Üí### Blog Post
    99‚Üí
   100‚Üí1. **Copy template:**
   101‚Üí```bash
   102‚Üícp content/_templates/blog-post.md content/blog/2024-12-15-my-post.md
   103‚Üí```
   104‚Üí
   105‚Üí**Important:** Filename must follow `YYYY-MM-DD-slug.md` format
   106‚Üí
   107‚Üí2. **Edit frontmatter:**
   108‚Üí   - Update `title`
   109‚Üí   - Set `date` (YYYY-MM-DD)

   111‚Üí   - Add relevant `tags`
   112‚Üí

   114‚Üí   - Markdown body below `---`
   115‚Üí   - Use headings, lists, code blocks
   116‚Üí   - Add images if needed
   117‚Üí
   118‚Üí4. **Validate:**
   119‚Üí```bash
   120‚Üínpm run validate
   121‚Üí```
   122‚Üí
   123‚Üí---
   124‚Üí
   125‚Üí## Content Validation
   126‚Üí
   127‚Üí### Automatic Validation
   128‚Üí
   129‚ÜíThe build process validates all content automatically:
   130‚Üí```bash
   131‚Üínpm run build  # Fails if content is invalid
   132‚Üí```
   133‚Üí
   134‚Üí### Manual Validation
   135‚Üí
   136‚ÜíRun validation CLI anytime:
   137‚Üí```bash
   138‚Üínpm run validate
   139‚Üí```
   140‚Üí
   141‚Üí**Output:**
   142‚Üí```
   143‚Üí‚úì Profile (profile.yaml)
   144‚Üí‚úì Case Study: 01-eth-staking.md
   145‚Üí‚úó Case Study: 05-new-project.md
   146‚Üí  ‚úó hook.impactMetric.value: Required
   147‚Üí  ‚úó year: Invalid format
   148‚Üí```
   149‚Üí
   150‚Üí### What Gets Validated
   151‚Üí
   152‚Üí- ‚úÖ **Required fields** - No missing data
   153‚Üí- ‚úÖ **Data types** - Strings, numbers, arrays
   154‚Üí- ‚úÖ **Format** - Dates, emails, URLs
   155‚Üí- ‚úÖ **Nested objects** - hook, cta, media
   156‚Üí- ‚úÖ **Arrays** - tags, subMetrics, highlights
   157‚Üí
   158‚Üí---
   159‚Üí
   160‚Üí## Field Reference
   161‚Üí
   162‚Üí### Case Study Frontmatter
   163‚Üí
   164‚Üí**Required:**
   165‚Üí```yaml
   166‚Üíid: 5                    # Number, unique, incremental
   167‚Üíslug: my-project         # String, URL-friendly
   168‚Üítitle: Project Title     # String
   169‚Üícompany: Company Name    # String
   170‚Üíyear: 2024-25           # String (YYYY or YYYY-YY)
   171‚Üítags: [Tag1, Tag2]      # Array of strings
   172‚Üíduration: 6 months       # String
   173‚Üírole: Product Manager    # String
   174‚Üí
   175‚Üíhook:
   176‚Üí  headline: One-liner    # String
   177‚Üí  impactMetric:
   178‚Üí    value: "50%"        # String (can include symbols)
   179‚Üí    label: improvement   # String
   180‚Üí  thumbnail: /images/x.png  # String or null
   181‚Üí
   182‚Üícta:
   183‚Üí  headline: CTA text     # String
   184‚Üí  action: calendly       # Enum: contact|calendly|linkedin
   185‚Üí  linkText: Let's talk ‚Üí # String
   186‚Üí```
   187‚Üí
   188‚Üí**Optional:**
   189‚Üí```yaml
   190‚ÜídemoUrl: https://...           # String or null
   191‚ÜígithubUrl: https://...         # String or null
   192‚ÜídocsUrl: https://...           # String or null
   193‚Üí
   194‚Üíhook:
   195‚Üí  subMetrics:                  # Array (optional)
   196‚Üí    - value: "10K"
   197‚Üí      label: users
   198‚Üí
   199‚Üímedia:                         # Array (optional)
   200‚Üí  - type: blog                 # Enum: blog|twitter|linkedin|video|article|slides
   201‚Üí    url: https://...
   202‚Üí    label: Custom Label        # String (optional)
   203‚Üí
   204‚Üícta:
   205‚Üí  subtext: Additional text     # String (optional)
   206‚Üí```
   207‚Üí
   208‚Üí---
   209‚Üí
   210‚Üí### Blog Post Frontmatter
   211‚Üí
   212‚Üí**Required:**
   213‚Üí```yaml
   214‚Üítitle: "Post Title"       # String (quoted)
   215‚Üídate: "2024-12-15"        # String, YYYY-MM-DD format
   216‚Üíexcerpt: "Description"    # String (quoted)
   217‚Üítags: ["Tag1", "Tag2"]    # Array of strings
   218‚Üí```
   219‚Üí
   220‚Üí**Optional:**
   221‚Üí```yaml
   222‚Üíthumbnail: /images/thumb.png  # String or null
   223‚Üí```
   224‚Üí
   225‚Üí---
   226‚Üí
   227‚Üí### Passion Project Entry
   228‚Üí
   229‚Üí**Required:**
   230‚Üí```yaml
   231‚Üíid: 10                   # Number, unique
   232‚Üíslug: project-slug       # String, URL-friendly
   233‚Üítitle: Project Name      # String
   234‚Üítagline: One-liner       # String
   235‚Üíyear: "2024"            # String (quoted)
   236‚Üítags: [Tag1, Tag2]      # Array
   237‚Üí```
   238‚Üí
   239‚Üí**Optional:**
   240‚Üí```yaml
   241‚Üíthumbnail: null          # String or null
   242‚ÜígithubUrl: null          # String or null
   243‚ÜíliveUrl: null            # String or null
   244‚ÜídocsUrl: null            # String or null
   245‚Üí```
   246‚Üí
   247‚Üí---
   248‚Üí
   249‚Üí## Common Tasks
   250‚Üí
   251‚Üí### Get Next Available ID
   252‚Üí
   253‚Üí**Case Studies:**
   254‚Üí```bash
   255‚Üí# Count existing + 1
   256‚Üíls content/case-studies/*.md | wc -l
   257‚Üí# Next ID = count + 1
   258‚Üí```
   259‚Üí
   260‚Üí**Passion Projects:**
   261‚Üí```bash
   262‚Üí# Find highest ID
   263‚Üígrep 'id:' content/passion-projects/index.yaml | sort -n | tail -1
   264‚Üí# Add 1
   265‚Üí```
   266‚Üí
   267‚Üí### Toggle Section Visibility
   268‚Üí
   269‚ÜíEdit `content/profile.yaml`:
   270‚Üí```yaml
   271‚Üísections:
   272‚Üí  beyondWork: false
   273‚Üí  blog: true           # Show/hide blog section
   274‚Üí  onchainIdentity: false
   275‚Üí  skills: false
   276‚Üí  passionProjects: true  # Show/hide passion projects
   277‚Üí```
   278‚Üí
   279‚Üí### Update Profile Stats
   280‚Üí
   281‚ÜíEdit `content/profile.yaml`:
   282‚Üí```yaml
   283‚Üíabout:
   284‚Üí  stats:
   285‚Üí    - value: "8+"
   286‚Üí      label: "Years in Product"
   287‚Üí    - value: "5"
   288‚Üí      label: "Years in Web3"
   289‚Üí```
   290‚Üí
   291‚Üí### Add Social Link
   292‚Üí
   293‚ÜíEdit `content/social/index.yaml`:
   294‚Üí```yaml
   295‚Üílinks:
   296‚Üí  - platform: GitHub
   297‚Üí    label: "@username"
   298‚Üí    url: https://github.com/username
   299‚Üí    icon: github
   300‚Üí    primary: true
   301‚Üí```
   302‚Üí
   303‚Üí---
   304‚Üí
   305‚Üí## Best Practices
   306‚Üí
   307‚Üí### Content Writing
   308‚Üí
   309‚Üí1. **Headlines** - One sentence, active voice, metric-driven
   310‚Üí2. **Slugs** - Lowercase, hyphens, descriptive
   311‚Üí3. **Tags** - 3-5 relevant tags, consistent naming
   312‚Üí4. **Metrics** - Specific numbers, context-aware labels
   313‚Üí5. **Images** - Store in `/public/images/`, reference as `/images/name.png`
   314‚Üí
   315‚Üí### File Organization
   316‚Üí
   317‚Üí```
   318‚Üícontent/
   319‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ _templates/          # Templates (don't edit originals)
   320‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ case-studies/        # One file per case study
   321‚Üí‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 01-project.md
   322‚Üí‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 02-project.md
   323‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ blog/                # Date-prefixed files
   324‚Üí‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ YYYY-MM-DD-slug.md
   325‚Üí‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ passion-projects/
   326‚Üí    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ index.yaml       # All projects in one file
   327‚Üí```
   328‚Üí
   329‚Üí### Validation Workflow
   330‚Üí
   331‚Üí```bash
   332‚Üí# 1. Make changes
   333‚Üívim content/case-studies/05-new-project.md
   334‚Üí
   335‚Üí# 2. Validate
   336‚Üínpm run validate
   337‚Üí
   338‚Üí# 3. Fix errors if any
   339‚Üí# 4. Preview locally
   340‚Üínpm run dev
   341‚Üí
   342‚Üí# 5. Commit
   343‚Üígit add content/
   344‚Üígit commit -m "Add new case study"
   345‚Üí```
   346‚Üí
   347‚Üí---
   348‚Üí
   349‚Üí## Troubleshooting
   350‚Üí
   351‚Üí### Validation Errors
   352‚Üí
   353‚Üí**"Required field missing"**
   354‚Üí- Check template for required fields
   355‚Üí- Ensure no typos in field names
   356‚Üí
   357‚Üí**"Invalid date format"**
   358‚Üí- Dates must be `YYYY-MM-DD`
   359‚Üí- Wrap in quotes: `"2024-12-15"`
   360‚Üí
   361‚Üí**"Invalid year format"**
   362‚Üí- Use `2024` or `2024-25` format
   363‚Üí- No other formats accepted
   364‚Üí
   365‚Üí**"Frontmatter parse error"**
   366‚Üí- Check YAML syntax
   367‚Üí- Ensure proper indentation (2 spaces)
   368‚Üí- Quotes around strings with special chars
   369‚Üí
   370‚Üí### Build Errors
   371‚Üí
   372‚Üí**"Cannot find module"**
   373‚Üí- File might be outside `content/` directory
   374‚Üí- Check file paths in frontmatter
   375‚Üí
   376‚Üí**"Zod validation failed"**
   377‚Üí- Run `npm run validate` for details
   378‚Üí- Fix indicated fields
   379‚Üí
   380‚Üí### Hot Reload Not Working
   381‚Üí
   382‚Üí```bash
   383‚Üí# Restart dev server
   384‚Üínpm run dev
   385‚Üí```
   386‚Üí
   387‚Üí---
   388‚Üí
   389‚Üí## Advanced
   390‚Üí
   391‚Üí### Custom Validation
   392‚Üí
   393‚ÜíSchemas are in `src/lib/schemas.ts`. To add custom validation:
   394‚Üí
   395‚Üí```typescript
   396‚Üí// Add to existing schema
   397‚Üíexport const CustomSchema = z.object({
   398‚Üí  field: z.string().min(10).max(100),
   399‚Üí  url: z.string().url(),
   400‚Üí  email: z.string().email()
   401‚Üí});
   402‚Üí```
   403‚Üí
   404‚Üí### Pre-commit Hook
   405‚Üí
   406‚ÜíAdd validation to git hooks (optional):
   407‚Üí
   408‚Üí```bash
   409‚Üí# .git/hooks/pre-commit
   410‚Üí#!/bin/sh
   411‚Üínpm run validate || exit 1
   412‚Üí```
   413‚Üí
   414‚Üí---
   415‚Üí
   416‚Üí## Quick Reference
   417‚Üí
   418‚Üí| Task | Command |
   419‚Üí|------|---------|
   420‚Üí| Validate content | `npm run validate` |
   421‚Üí| Start dev server | `npm run dev` |
   422‚Üí| Build for production | `npm run build` |
   423‚Üí| Run tests | `npm test` |
   424‚Üí| Find templates | `ls content/_templates/` |

   431‚Üí- **Schemas**: `/src/lib/schemas.ts`

_**Agent (claude-haiku-4-5-20251001) (sidechain)**_

<tool-use data-tool-type="read" data-tool-name="Read"><details>
<summary>Tool use: **Read**</summary>
 `./docs/guides/universal-cv.md`
```
     1‚Üí# Universal CV System - Complete Guide
     2‚Üí
     3‚Üí## Overview
     4‚Üí
     5‚ÜíThe Universal CV system allows you to create personalized portfolio variants tailored to specific job applications. Each variant customizes your hero section, bio, stats, and content emphasis while maintaining factual accuracy.
     6‚Üí
     7‚Üí## Live Examples
     8‚Üí
     9‚Üí- **Base Portfolio**: `https://edgeoftrust.com/#/`
    10‚Üí- **Bloomberg (TPM)**: `https://edgeoftrust.com/#/bloomberg/technical-product-manager`
    11‚Üí- **Gensyn (TPM)**: `https://edgeoftrust.com/#/gensyn/technical-product-manager`
    12‚Üí
    13‚Üí---
    14‚Üí
    15‚Üí## Architecture
    16‚Üí
    17‚Üí### URL Structure
    18‚Üí```
    19‚Üí/#/:company/:role
    20‚Üí```
    21‚Üí
    22‚ÜíExamples:
    23‚Üí- `/#/bloomberg/technical-product-manager`
    24‚Üí- `/#/stripe/senior-pm`
    25‚Üí- `/#/databricks/ml-platform-lead`
    26‚Üí
    27‚Üí### Data Flow
    28‚Üí
    29‚Üí```
    30‚Üí1. User visits /#/bloomberg/technical-product-manager
    31‚Üí2. React Router captures params: { company: "bloomberg", role: "technical-product-manager" }
    32‚Üí3. VariantPortfolio loads variant JSON: bloomberg-technical-product-manager.json
    33‚Üí4. mergeProfile() combines base profile + variant overrides
    34‚Üí5. VariantContext provides merged profile to Portfolio component
    35‚Üí6. Sections render personalized content
    36‚Üí```
    37‚Üí
    38‚Üí### File Structure
    39‚Üí
    40‚Üí```
    41‚Üícontent/variants/
    42‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md                                    # Variant documentation
    43‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ _template.yaml                               # Template for new variants
    44‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ bloomberg-technical-product-manager.yaml     # Human-readable source
    45‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ bloomberg-technical-product-manager.json     # Client-side loading
    46‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ gensyn-technical-product-manager.yaml
    47‚Üí‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ gensyn-technical-product-manager.json
    48‚Üí```
    49‚Üí
    50‚Üí---
    51‚Üí
    52‚Üí## Creating a New Variant
    53‚Üí
    54‚Üí### Method 1: CLI Generator (Recommended)
    55‚Üí
    56‚Üí```bash
    57‚Üí# Set API key
    58‚Üíexport GEMINI_API_KEY=your_key_here
    59‚Üí
    60‚Üí# Generate variant
    61‚Üínpm run generate:cv -- \
    62‚Üí  --company "Stripe" \
    63‚Üí  --role "Senior PM" \
    64‚Üí  --jd "./stripe-jd.txt" \
    65‚Üí  --provider gemini
    66‚Üí
    67‚Üí# Or inline job description
    68‚Üínpm run generate:cv -- \
    69‚Üí  --company "Databricks" \
    70‚Üí  --role "ML Platform Lead" \
    71‚Üí  --jd-text "Job description here..." \
    72‚Üí  --provider gemini
    73‚Üí```
    74‚Üí
    75‚Üí**CLI Options:**
    76‚Üí- `--company <name>` - Company name (required)
    77‚Üí- `--role <title>` - Role title (required)
    78‚Üí- `--jd <file>` - Path to job description file
    79‚Üí- `--jd-text <text>` - Job description as inline text
    80‚Üí- `--values <text>` - Company values (optional)
    81‚Üí- `--context <text>` - Additional context (optional)
    82‚Üí- `--provider <name>` - AI provider: `claude` | `openai` | `gemini` (default: claude)
    83‚Üí- `--api-key <key>` - API key (or use env var)
    84‚Üí- `--output <file>` - Output file path (auto-generated if not specified)
    85‚Üí
    86‚Üí**Supported AI Providers:**
    87‚Üí- **Claude** (Anthropic): `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY`
    88‚Üí- **OpenAI**: `OPENAI_API_KEY`
    89‚Üí- **Gemini** (Google): `GEMINI_API_KEY`
    90‚Üí
    91‚Üí### Method 2: Manual Creation
    92‚Üí
    93‚Üí1. **Copy template:**
    94‚Üí   ```bash
    95‚Üí   cp content/variants/_template.yaml content/variants/company-role.yaml
    96‚Üí   ```
    97‚Üí
    98‚Üí2. **Edit YAML file** with variant overrides
    99‚Üí
   100‚Üí3. **Generate JSON:**
   101‚Üí   ```bash
   102‚Üí   npx tsx -e "
   103‚Üí   import { readFileSync, writeFileSync } from 'fs';
   104‚Üí   import YAML from 'yaml';
   105‚Üí   const yaml = readFileSync('content/variants/company-role.yaml', 'utf-8');
   106‚Üí   writeFileSync('content/variants/company-role.json', JSON.stringify(YAML.parse(yaml), null, 2));
   107‚Üí   "
   108‚Üí   ```
   109‚Üí
   110‚Üí4. **Validate:**
   111‚Üí   ```bash
   112‚Üí   npm run validate
   113‚Üí   ```
   114‚Üí
   115‚Üí---
   116‚Üí
   117‚Üí## Variant Schema
   118‚Üí
   119‚Üí### Metadata
   120‚Üí
   121‚Üí```yaml
   122‚Üímetadata:
   123‚Üí  company: "Bloomberg"                          # Company name
   124‚Üí  role: "Technical Product Manager"            # Role title
   125‚Üí  slug: "bloomberg-technical-product-manager"  # URL slug (lowercase-hyphenated)
   126‚Üí  generatedAt: "2025-12-16T18:30:00Z"          # ISO timestamp
   127‚Üí  jobDescription: |                            # Full job description
   128‚Üí    Job requirements here...
   129‚Üí  generationModel: "claude-3-5-sonnet"         # AI model used
   130‚Üí```
   131‚Üí
   132‚Üí### Overrides
   133‚Üí
   134‚ÜíOverride specific profile fields for personalization:
   135‚Üí
   136‚Üí```yaml
   137‚Üíoverrides:
   138‚Üí  hero:
   139‚Üí    status: "Open to Technical PM roles ‚Äî Platform Architecture, Developer Tools"
   140‚Üí    headline:
   141‚Üí      - text: "Building"
   142‚Üí        style: "italic"
   143‚Üí      - text: "developer platforms at the intersection of"
   144‚Üí        style: "muted"
   145‚Üí      - text: "scale and innovation"
   146‚Üí        style: "accent"
   147‚Üí    subheadline: >
   148‚Üí      Personalized elevator pitch emphasizing relevant experience
   149‚Üí
   150‚Üí  about:
   151‚Üí    tagline: >
   152‚Üí      Professional summary highlighting job fit
   153‚Üí    bio:
   154‚Üí      - "First paragraph: current role and relevant experience..."
   155‚Üí      - "Second paragraph: career journey leading to this role..."
   156‚Üí    stats:
   157‚Üí      - value: "8+"
   158‚Üí        label: "Years Platform PM"
   159‚Üí      - value: "7+"
   160‚Üí        label: "SDK/API Products"
   161‚Üí
   162‚Üí  sections:
   163‚Üí    beyondWork: false      # Show/hide sections based on job relevance
   164‚Üí    blog: true
   165‚Üí    onchainIdentity: false
   166‚Üí    skills: true
   167‚Üí    passionProjects: true
   168‚Üí```
   169‚Üí
   170‚Üí### Relevance Scoring
   171‚Üí
   172‚ÜíAI ranks your existing content by relevance (0.0-1.0):
   173‚Üí
   174‚Üí```yaml
   175‚Üírelevance:
   176‚Üí  caseStudies:
   177‚Üí    - slug: "developer-analytics"
   178‚Üí      relevanceScore: 0.95
   179‚Üí      reasoning: "Direct SDK/platform architecture experience"
   180‚Üí    - slug: "ankr-rpc"
   181‚Üí      relevanceScore: 0.90
   182‚Üí      reasoning: "API platform growth demonstrates stakeholder management"
   183‚Üí
   184‚Üí  skills:
   185‚Üí    - category: "Technical Leadership"
   186‚Üí      relevanceScore: 1.0
   187‚Üí    - category: "Product Strategy"
   188‚Üí      relevanceScore: 0.95
   189‚Üí
   190‚Üí  projects:
   191‚Üí    - slug: "ai-agent-framework"
   192‚Üí      relevanceScore: 0.85
   193‚Üí      reasoning: "Demonstrates ML infrastructure experience"
   194‚Üí```
   195‚Üí
   196‚Üí---
   197‚Üí
   198‚Üí## Personalization Strategy
   199‚Üí
   200‚Üí### What Gets Personalized
   201‚Üí
   202‚Üí‚úÖ **Hero Section**
   203‚Üí- Status line (role type emphasis)
   204‚Üí- Headline (key value proposition)
   205‚Üí- Subheadline (tailored elevator pitch)
   206‚Üí
   207‚Üí‚úÖ **About Section**
   208‚Üí- Tagline (professional summary)
   209‚Üí- Bio paragraphs (career narrative)
   210‚Üí- Stats (metrics that matter for role)
   211‚Üí
   212‚Üí‚úÖ **Section Visibility**
   213‚Üí- Show/hide sections based on job fit
   214‚Üí- Example: Show onchain identity for Web3 roles, hide for traditional tech
   215‚Üí
   216‚Üí‚úÖ **Content Ordering**
   217‚Üí- Case studies ranked by relevance
   218‚Üí- Skills emphasized by category
   219‚Üí- Projects highlighted by fit
   220‚Üí
   221‚Üí### What Stays Consistent
   222‚Üí
   223‚Üí‚ùå **Factual Content**
   224‚Üí- Case study text unchanged
   225‚Üí- Experience details unchanged
   226‚Üí- All achievements remain truthful
   227‚Üí
   228‚Üí‚ùå **Design & Brand**
   229‚Üí- Same visual design system
   230‚Üí- Same navigation and UX
   231‚Üí- Same color scheme and typography
   232‚Üí
   233‚Üí---
   234‚Üí
   235‚Üí## Best Practices
   236‚Üí
   237‚Üí### 1. Gather Comprehensive Info
   238‚Üí
   239‚ÜíBefore generating:
   240‚Üí- Full job description
   241‚Üí- Company values/culture research
   242‚Üí- Specific technologies mentioned
   243‚Üí- Role emphasis (technical vs. strategic vs. people leadership)
   244‚Üí
   245‚Üí### 2. Review & Refine
   246‚Üí
   247‚ÜíAfter generation:
   248‚Üí- Review hero headline for impact
   249‚Üí- Ensure bio flows naturally
   250‚Üí- Verify stats are relevant
   251‚Üí- Check section visibility makes sense
   252‚Üí
   253‚Üí### 3. Test Before Sharing
   254‚Üí
   255‚Üí```bash
   256‚Üí# Local testing
   257‚Üínpm run dev
   258‚Üí# Visit: http://localhost:5173/#/company/role
   259‚Üí
   260‚Üí# Validate content
   261‚Üínpm run validate
   262‚Üí
   263‚Üí# Build for production
   264‚Üínpm run build
   265‚Üí```
   266‚Üí
   267‚Üí### 4. Naming Conventions
   268‚Üí
   269‚Üí**Slugs:** Use lowercase with hyphens
   270‚Üí- ‚úÖ `bloomberg-technical-product-manager`
   271‚Üí- ‚ùå `Bloomberg_Technical_Product_Manager`
   272‚Üí
   273‚Üí**Files:** Match slug exactly
   274‚Üí- `{slug}.yaml` - Human-readable source
   275‚Üí- `{slug}.json` - Client-side loading
   276‚Üí
   277‚Üí---
   278‚Üí
   279‚Üí## Editing Existing Variants
   280‚Üí
   281‚Üí### Update YAML Source
   282‚Üí
   283‚Üí```bash
   284‚Üí# Edit the human-readable YAML
   285‚Üívim content/variants/bloomberg-technical-product-manager.yaml
   286‚Üí
   287‚Üí# Regenerate JSON
   288‚Üínpx tsx -e "
   289‚Üíimport { readFileSync, writeFileSync } from 'fs';
   290‚Üíimport YAML from 'yaml';
   291‚Üíconst yaml = readFileSync('content/variants/bloomberg-technical-product-manager.yaml', 'utf-8');
   292‚ÜíwriteFileSync('content/variants/bloomberg-technical-product-manager.json',
   293‚Üí  JSON.stringify(YAML.parse(yaml), null, 2));
   294‚Üí"
   295‚Üí
   296‚Üí# Validate
   297‚Üínpm run validate
   298‚Üí
   299‚Üí# Test
   300‚Üínpm run dev
   301‚Üí```
   302‚Üí
   303‚Üí---
   304‚Üí
   305‚Üí## Deployment
   306‚Üí
   307‚Üí### GitHub Pages (Current Setup)
   308‚Üí
   309‚ÜíUsing HashRouter for client-side routing:
   310‚Üí
   311‚Üí```bash
   312‚Üí# Merge PR
   313‚Üígit checkout main
   314‚Üígit pull origin main
   315‚Üí
   316‚Üí# GitHub Pages auto-deploys
   317‚Üí
   318‚Üí# Test live URLs
   319‚Üíhttps://edgeoftrust.com/#/bloomberg/technical-product-manager
   320‚Üíhttps://edgeoftrust.com/#/gensyn/technical-product-manager
   321‚Üí```
   322‚Üí
   323‚Üí### Alternative Hosting
   324‚Üí
   325‚ÜíFor **Vercel/Netlify** (clean URLs without hash):
   326‚Üí
   327‚Üí1. Switch back to BrowserRouter in `src/App.tsx`
   328‚Üí2. Add rewrites config (see section below)
   329‚Üí3. Deploy
   330‚Üí
   331‚Üí**Vercel** (`vercel.json`):
   332‚Üí```json
   333‚Üí{
   334‚Üí  "rewrites": [
   335‚Üí    { "source": "/(.*)", "destination": "/index.html" }
   336‚Üí  ]
   337‚Üí}
   338‚Üí```
   339‚Üí
   340‚Üí**Netlify** (`netlify.toml`):
   341‚Üí```toml
   342‚Üí[[redirects]]
   343‚Üí  from = "/*"
   344‚Üí  to = "/index.html"
   345‚Üí  status = 200
   346‚Üí```
   347‚Üí
   348‚Üí---
   349‚Üí
   350‚Üí## Troubleshooting
   351‚Üí
   352‚Üí### Variant Not Loading
   353‚Üí
   354‚Üí**Issue:** Variant URL shows base portfolio
   355‚Üí
   356‚Üí**Checks:**
   357‚Üí1. ‚úÖ JSON file exists: `content/variants/{slug}.json`
   358‚Üí2. ‚úÖ Slug matches URL: `/#/company/role` ‚Üí `company-role.json`
   359‚Üí3. ‚úÖ File validates: `npm run validate`
   360‚Üí4. ‚úÖ Build includes variant: Check `dist/assets/` for variant chunk
   361‚Üí
   362‚Üí**Debug:**
   363‚Üí```bash
   364‚Üí# Check if variant file exists
   365‚Üíls -la content/variants/
   366‚Üí
   367‚Üí# Validate schema
   368‚Üínpm run validate
   369‚Üí
   370‚Üí# Check build output
   371‚Üínpm run build | grep "technical-product-manager"
   372‚Üí
   373‚Üí# Test locally
   374‚Üínpm run dev
   375‚Üí# Open browser console at /#/company/role
   376‚Üí```
   377‚Üí
   378‚Üí### Sections Not Personalizing
   379‚Üí
   380‚Üí**Issue:** Hero/About look the same as base
   381‚Üí
   382‚Üí**Fix:** Ensure sections receive profile prop (fixed in latest version)
   383‚Üí
   384‚Üí**Verify:**
   385‚Üí```tsx
   386‚Üí// src/components/Portfolio.tsx
   387‚Üí<HeroSection profile={profile} ... />  // ‚úÖ Has profile prop
   388‚Üí<HeroSection ... />  // ‚ùå Missing profile prop
   389‚Üí```
   390‚Üí
   391‚Üí### 404 on Variant URLs
   392‚Üí
   393‚Üí**Issue:** URLs return 404
   394‚Üí
   395‚Üí**Fix:** Using HashRouter for GitHub Pages
   396‚Üí- URLs must include `#`: `/#/company/role`
   397‚Üí- Not: `/company/role` (clean URLs need server config)
   398‚Üí
   399‚Üí---
   400‚Üí
   401‚Üí## Example Variants

   453‚Üí---
   454‚Üí
   455‚Üí## API Reference
   456‚Üí
   457‚Üí### loadVariant(slug: string)
   458‚Üí
   459‚ÜíLoads and validates a variant JSON file.
   460‚Üí
   461‚Üí```typescript
   462‚Üíimport { loadVariant } from '../lib/variants';
   463‚Üí
   464‚Üíconst variant = await loadVariant('bloomberg-technical-product-manager');
   465‚Üí// Returns: Variant | null
   466‚Üí```
   467‚Üí
   468‚Üí### mergeProfile(variant: Variant)
   469‚Üí
   470‚ÜíMerges base profile with variant overrides.
   471‚Üí
   472‚Üí```typescript
   473‚Üíimport { mergeProfile } from '../lib/variants';
   474‚Üí
   475‚Üíconst mergedProfile = mergeProfile(variant);
   476‚Üí// Returns: MergedProfile (Profile with overrides applied)
   477‚Üí```
   478‚Üí
   479‚Üí### VariantContext
   480‚Üí
   481‚ÜíProvides active profile to components.
   482‚Üí
   483‚Üí```typescript
   484‚Üíimport { useVariant } from '../context/VariantContext';
   485‚Üí
   486‚Üífunction MyComponent() {
   487‚Üí  const { profile, variant, isVariant } = useVariant();
   488‚Üí  // profile: Active profile (base or merged)
   489‚Üí  // variant: Variant data if active, null otherwise
   490‚Üí  // isVariant: Boolean flag
   491‚Üí}
   492‚Üí```
   493‚Üí
   494‚Üí---
   495‚Üí
   496‚Üí## Resources

   499‚Üí- **Schema Definition**: `src/lib/schemas.ts` ‚Üí `VariantSchema`
   500‚Üí- **Type Definitions**: `src/types/variant.ts`
   501‚Üí- **Loader Logic**: `src/lib/variants.ts`

_**Agent (claude-haiku-4-5-20251001) (sidechain)**_

<tool-use data-tool-type="read" data-tool-name="Read"><details>
<summary>Tool use: **Read**</summary>
 `./docs/guides/capstone-workflow.md`
```
     1‚Üí# Capstone Quality Pipeline: Step-by-Step Workflow
     2‚Üí
     3‚ÜíThis guide walks you through the complete quality pipeline for a variant, using `mysten-walrus-senior-pm` as a working example.
     4‚Üí
     5‚Üí---
     6‚Üí
     7‚Üí## Quick Reference: File Locations
     8‚Üí
     9‚Üí| What | Where | Purpose |
    10‚Üí|------|-------|---------|
    11‚Üí| **Variant YAML** | `content/variants/<slug>.yaml` | Source of truth (edit this) |
    12‚Üí| **Variant JSON** | `content/variants/<slug>.json` | Runtime artifact (auto-generated) |
    13‚Üí| **Knowledge Base** | `content/knowledge/achievements/*.yaml` | Facts & metrics source |
    14‚Üí| **Claims Ledger** | `capstone/develop/evals/<slug>.claims.yaml` | Extracted claims + verification status |
    15‚Üí| **Eval Checklist** | `capstone/develop/evals/<slug>.eval.md` | Human-readable checklist |
    16‚Üí| **Red Team Report** | `capstone/develop/redteam/<slug>.redteam.md` | Adversarial scan results |
    17‚Üí| **Evaluation Rubric** | `capstone/develop/evaluation.md` | How claims are evaluated |
    18‚Üí| **Threat Model** | `capstone/develop/red-teaming.md` | Red team check definitions |
    19‚Üí
    20‚Üí---
    21‚Üí
    22‚Üí## The Pipeline Flow
    23‚Üí
    24‚Üí```
    25‚Üí‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
    26‚Üí‚îÇ  1. SYNC          2. EVALUATE         3. RED TEAM         4. SHIP          ‚îÇ
    27‚Üí‚îÇ                                                                             ‚îÇ
    28‚Üí‚îÇ  YAML ‚Üí JSON      Extract claims      Adversarial         Deploy if        ‚îÇ
    29‚Üí‚îÇ  (deterministic)  Find sources        scans               gates pass       ‚îÇ
    30‚Üí‚îÇ                   Mark verified                                             ‚îÇ
    31‚Üí‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
    32‚Üí```
    33‚Üí
    34‚Üí---
    35‚Üí
    36‚Üí## Step 1: Sync Variants
    37‚Üí
    38‚Üí**Purpose**: Convert YAML (human-editable) to JSON (runtime artifact).
    39‚Üí
    40‚Üí```bash
    41‚Üínpm run variants:sync
    42‚Üí```
    43‚Üí
    44‚Üí**What happens**:
    45‚Üí- Reads all `content/variants/*.yaml` files
    46‚Üí- Validates against Zod schema
    47‚Üí- Writes `content/variants/*.json` files
    48‚Üí
    49‚Üí**Check for drift**:
    50‚Üí```bash
    51‚Üínpm run variants:check
    52‚Üí```
    53‚ÜíFails if JSON doesn't match YAML (useful in CI).
    54‚Üí
    55‚Üí**Output**: JSON files in `content/variants/`
    56‚Üí
    57‚Üí---
    58‚Üí
    59‚Üí## Step 2: Generate Claims Ledger
    60‚Üí
    61‚Üí**Purpose**: Extract all metric-like claims and find candidate sources.
    62‚Üí
    63‚Üí```bash
    64‚Üínpm run eval:variant -- --slug mysten-walrus-senior-pm
    65‚Üí```
    66‚Üí
    67‚Üí**What happens**:
    68‚Üí1. Parses the variant YAML
    69‚Üí2. Extracts claims containing metrics (%, $, √ó, numbers)
    70‚Üí3. Searches knowledge base for matching sources
    71‚Üí4. Generates a claims ledger with candidate sources
    72‚Üí
    73‚Üí**Outputs created**:
    74‚Üí- `capstone/develop/evals/mysten-walrus-senior-pm.claims.yaml` - Machine-readable ledger
    75‚Üí- `capstone/develop/evals/mysten-walrus-senior-pm.eval.md` - Human checklist
    76‚Üí
    77‚Üí### Understanding the Claims Ledger
    78‚Üí
    79‚ÜíOpen `capstone/develop/evals/<slug>.claims.yaml`:
    80‚Üí
    81‚Üí```yaml
    82‚Üíclaims:
    83‚Üí  - id: metric-1080fe1903
    84‚Üí    location: overrides.hero.subheadline    # Where in variant
    85‚Üí    text: "Senior PM with 8 years..."       # The claim text
    86‚Üí    anchors:
    87‚Üí      - 8 years                              # Key metric extracted
    88‚Üí    candidateSources:
    89‚Üí      - path: content/knowledge/achievements/...
    90‚Üí        score: 0.09
    91‚Üí        matchedAnchors: []
    92‚Üí        note: "anchors 0/1 ‚Ä¢ overlap 60%"
    93‚Üí    verified:
    94‚Üí      status: unverified                     # YOU EDIT THIS
    95‚Üí      sources: []
    96‚Üí      notes: ""
    97‚Üí```
    98‚Üí
    99‚Üí### Verifying Claims
   100‚Üí
   101‚ÜíFor each claim, you need to:
   102‚Üí
   103‚Üí1. **Check candidate sources** - Does a knowledge base file contain this fact?
   104‚Üí2. **Update verified status** - Change `unverified` ‚Üí `verified`
   105‚Üí3. **Add source path** - Reference the KB file that proves the claim
   106‚Üí4. **Add notes** - Optional context
   107‚Üí
   108‚Üí**Example: Before**
   109‚Üí```yaml
   110‚Üíverified:
   111‚Üí  status: unverified
   112‚Üí  sources: []
   113‚Üí  notes: ""
   114‚Üí```
   115‚Üí
   116‚Üí**Example: After**
   117‚Üí```yaml
   118‚Üíverified:
   119‚Üí  status: verified
   120‚Üí  sources:
   121‚Üí    - content/knowledge/achievements/l2-protocol-integrations.yaml
   122‚Üí  notes: "Anchor '7+ L2 integrations' matches KB exactly"
   123‚Üí```
   124‚Üí
   125‚Üí### If a claim has no source
   126‚Üí
   127‚ÜíTwo options:
   128‚Üí
   129‚Üí1. **Add to knowledge base** - Create/update a file in `content/knowledge/achievements/`
   130‚Üí2. **Reword the variant** - Change the claim in `content/variants/<slug>.yaml`
   131‚Üí
   132‚Üí**Golden Rule**: Fix facts in the knowledge base first, then regenerate.
   133‚Üí
   134‚Üí---
   135‚Üí
   136‚Üí## Step 3: Red Team Scan
   137‚Üí
   138‚Üí**Purpose**: Adversarial checks for security, tone, and accuracy risks.
   139‚Üí
   140‚Üí```bash
   141‚Üínpm run redteam:variant -- --slug mysten-walrus-senior-pm
   142‚Üí```
   143‚Üí
   144‚Üí**What happens**: Runs 8 checks against your variant:
   145‚Üí
   146‚Üí| Check | Severity | What It Catches |
   147‚Üí|-------|----------|-----------------|
   148‚Üí| `RT-ACC-CLAIMS` | FAIL | Missing/unverified claims ledger |
   149‚Üí| `RT-SEC-SECRETS` | FAIL | API keys, tokens in text |
   150‚Üí| `RT-SEC-CONFIDENTIAL` | FAIL | NDA/confidential language |
   151‚Üí| `RT-TONE-SYCOPHANCY` | WARN | "thrilled", "dream company" |
   152‚Üí| `RT-ACC-INFLATION` | WARN | "about 15√ó" near metrics |
   153‚Üí| `RT-INPUT-INJECTION` | WARN | Prompt injection in JD |
   154‚Üí| `RT-PRIV-JD` | WARN | Long JD exposed in public JSON |
   155‚Üí| `RT-XVAR-CONTAM` | WARN | Mentions other target company |
   156‚Üí
   157‚Üí**Output**: `capstone/develop/redteam/mysten-walrus-senior-pm.redteam.md`
   158‚Üí
   159‚Üí### Fixing Red Team Failures
   160‚Üí
   161‚Üí**RT-ACC-CLAIMS (most common)**:
   162‚Üí```
   163‚ÜíFAIL: Missing ledger
   164‚ÜíFix: npm run eval:variant -- --slug <slug>
   165‚Üí     Then verify claims in the .claims.yaml file
   166‚Üí```
   167‚Üí
   168‚Üí**RT-TONE-SYCOPHANCY**:
   169‚Üí```
   170‚ÜíWARN: "thrilled", "dream company" detected
   171‚ÜíFix: Edit content/variants/<slug>.yaml
   172‚Üí     Remove sycophantic language
   173‚Üí```
   174‚Üí
   175‚Üí**RT-SEC-SECRETS**:
   176‚Üí```
   177‚ÜíFAIL: API key pattern detected
   178‚ÜíFix: Remove the secret from variant YAML immediately
   179‚Üí```
   180‚Üí
   181‚Üí---
   182‚Üí
   183‚Üí## Step 4: Gate Check (CI Mode)
   184‚Üí
   185‚Üí**Purpose**: Pass/fail gate for deployment.
   186‚Üí
   187‚Üí```bash
   188‚Üí# Check all variants pass evaluation
   189‚Üínpm run eval:check
   190‚Üí
   191‚Üí# Check all variants pass red team (WARN ok)
   192‚Üínpm run redteam:check
   193‚Üí
   194‚Üí# Strict mode (WARN = FAIL)
   195‚Üínpm run redteam:check -- --strict
   196‚Üí```
   197‚Üí
   198‚Üí**Exit codes**:
   199‚Üí- `0` = All checks pass
   200‚Üí- `1` = At least one failure
   201‚Üí
   202‚Üí---
   203‚Üí
   204‚Üí## Complete Example: mysten-walrus-senior-pm
   205‚Üí
   206‚Üí### 1. Sync
   207‚Üí
   208‚Üí```bash
   209‚Üínpm run variants:sync
   210‚Üí```
   211‚Üí```
   212‚Üí‚úì mysten-walrus-senior-pm (in sync)
   213‚Üí```
   214‚Üí
   215‚Üí### 2. Evaluate
   216‚Üí
   217‚Üí```bash
   218‚Üínpm run eval:variant -- --slug mysten-walrus-senior-pm
   219‚Üí```
   220‚Üí```
   221‚Üí‚úì mysten-walrus-senior-pm: 5 claims, 0 verified, 5 unverified
   222‚Üí  capstone/develop/evals/mysten-walrus-senior-pm.claims.yaml
   223‚Üí```
   224‚Üí
   225‚Üí### 3. Verify Claims
   226‚Üí
   227‚ÜíOpen `capstone/develop/evals/mysten-walrus-senior-pm.claims.yaml`
   228‚Üí
   229‚ÜíFor each claim:
   230‚Üí1. Check if `candidateSources` has a good match (score > 0.5)
   231‚Üí2. Verify the anchor text matches the KB file
   232‚Üí3. Update `verified.status` to `verified`
   233‚Üí4. Add the source path
   234‚Üí
   235‚Üí### 4. Red Team
   236‚Üí
   237‚Üí```bash
   238‚Üínpm run redteam:variant -- --slug mysten-walrus-senior-pm
   239‚Üí```
   240‚Üí```
   241‚Üí‚úó mysten-walrus-senior-pm 1 FAIL 0 WARN
   242‚Üí```
   243‚Üí
   244‚ÜíCheck `capstone/develop/redteam/mysten-walrus-senior-pm.redteam.md`:
   245‚Üí```
   246‚ÜíRT-ACC-CLAIMS: FAIL - Missing/unverified claims
   247‚Üí```
   248‚Üí
   249‚Üí### 5. Fix & Iterate
   250‚Üí
   251‚ÜíFix unverified claims ‚Üí Re-run eval ‚Üí Re-run redteam ‚Üí Repeat until clean.
   252‚Üí
   253‚Üí### 6. Final Gate
   254‚Üí
   255‚Üí```bash
   256‚Üínpm run eval:check && npm run redteam:check
   257‚Üí```
   258‚Üí```
   259‚Üí‚úì All variants pass
   260‚Üí```
   261‚Üí
   262‚Üí---
   263‚Üí
   264‚Üí## Adding New Knowledge Base Entries
   265‚Üí
   266‚ÜíIf a claim has no source, add it to the knowledge base:
   267‚Üí
   268‚Üí```bash
   269‚Üí# Create new achievement file
   270‚Üítouch content/knowledge/achievements/my-new-achievement.yaml
   271‚Üí```
   272‚Üí
   273‚Üí**Template** (`content/knowledge/achievements/*.yaml`):
   274‚Üí```yaml
   275‚Üíid: my-new-achievement
   276‚Üítype: achievement
   277‚Üítitle: "Short descriptive title"
   278‚Üícompany: Company Name
   279‚Üítimeframe: "2023-2024"
   280‚Üísituation: |
   281‚Üí  Brief context (STAR format)
   282‚Üítask: |
   283‚Üí  What needed to be done
   284‚Üíaction: |
   285‚Üí  What you specifically did
   286‚Üíresult: |
   287‚Üí  Quantified outcomes
   288‚Üímetrics:
   289‚Üí  - value: "15√ó"
   290‚Üí    label: "revenue increase"
   291‚Üí    context: "Year-over-year growth"
   292‚Üítags:
   293‚Üí  - web3
   294‚Üí  - infrastructure
   295‚Üí```
   296‚Üí
   297‚ÜíAfter adding, re-run evaluation to pick up the new source.
   298‚Üí
   299‚Üí---
   300‚Üí
   301‚Üí## JSON Output for Automation
   302‚Üí
   303‚ÜíAll commands support `--json` for machine-readable output:
   304‚Üí
   305‚Üí```bash
   306‚Üínpm run variants:sync -- --json
   307‚Üínpm run eval:variant -- --slug mysten-walrus-senior-pm --json
   308‚Üínpm run redteam:all -- --json
   309‚Üí```
   310‚Üí
   311‚ÜíUseful for CI pipelines:
   312‚Üí```bash
   313‚Üínpm run redteam:all -- --json | jq '.errors | length'
   314‚Üí```
   315‚Üí
   316‚Üí---
   317‚Üí
   318‚Üí## Troubleshooting
   319‚Üí
   320‚Üí### "Variant YAML not found"
   321‚ÜíCheck the slug matches the filename:
   322‚Üí```bash
   323‚Üíls content/variants/*.yaml
   324‚Üí```
   325‚Üí
   326‚Üí### "Claims ledger missing"
   327‚ÜíRun evaluation first:
   328‚Üí```bash
   329‚Üínpm run eval:variant -- --slug <slug>
   330‚Üí```
   331‚Üí
   332‚Üí### "All claims unverified"
   333‚ÜíYou need to manually verify each claim in `.claims.yaml`.
   334‚ÜíThe script finds candidates but doesn't auto-verify.
   335‚Üí
   336‚Üí### "Red team fails on RT-ACC-CLAIMS"
   337‚ÜíThis means claims exist but aren't verified. Open the `.claims.yaml` and update the `verified` sections.
   338‚Üí
   339‚Üí---
   340‚Üí
   341‚Üí## Quick Commands Reference
   342‚Üí
   343‚Üí```bash
   344‚Üí# Sync all variants
   345‚Üínpm run variants:sync
   346‚Üí
   347‚Üí# Evaluate one variant
   348‚Üínpm run eval:variant -- --slug mysten-walrus-senior-pm
   349‚Üí
   350‚Üí# Evaluate all variants
   351‚Üínpm run eval:all
   352‚Üí
   353‚Üí# Red team one variant
   354‚Üínpm run redteam:variant -- --slug mysten-walrus-senior-pm
   355‚Üí
   356‚Üí# Red team all variants
   357‚Üínpm run redteam:all
   358‚Üí
   359‚Üí# CI gate checks
   360‚Üínpm run eval:check
   361‚Üínpm run redteam:check
   362‚Üínpm run redteam:check -- --strict
   363‚Üí```
   364‚Üí

But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

     4‚Üí---

     6‚Üí## Overview
     7‚Üí
     8‚ÜíThis framework defines how we evaluate the quality, accuracy, and safety of AI-generated content in Universal CV. Every generated variant must pass these evaluations before deployment.
     9‚Üí---

    18‚Üí  ```bash

    22‚Üí  ```bash

    24‚Üí  ```

    27‚Üí- `capstone/develop/evals/<slug>.claims.yaml` (verified claims + sources)

    49‚Üí```
    50‚Üí
    51‚Üí---
    52‚Üí
    53‚Üí## Dimension 1: Factual Accuracy
    54‚Üí
    55‚Üí**Definition:** Every claim in generated content must trace to the knowledge base.
    56‚Üí
    57‚Üí### Rubric
    58‚Üí
    59‚Üí| Score | Criteria | Example |
    60‚Üí|-------|----------|---------|
    61‚Üí| 5 | All claims exactly match knowledge base | "15√ó revenue growth" matches achievement file |
    62‚Üí| 4 | Minor paraphrasing, facts preserved | "Grew revenue 15-fold" (acceptable rephrase) |
    63‚Üí| 3 | Some facts compressed or simplified | "Significant revenue growth" (lost specificity) |
    64‚Üí| 2 | Metrics rounded or approximate | "Nearly 20√ó growth" (inflation) |
    65‚Üí| 1 | Claims not in knowledge base | Invented achievement |
    66‚Üí| 0 | Contradicts knowledge base | Wrong company, wrong metric |
    67‚Üí
    68‚Üí### Evaluation Method
    69‚Üí
    70‚Üí```yaml
    71‚Üíaccuracy_check:
    72‚Üí  process:
    73‚Üí    1. Extract all claims from generated content
    74‚Üí    2. For each claim, find source in knowledge base
    75‚Üí    3. Compare verbatim and semantic accuracy
    76‚Üí    4. Flag any untraced claims
    77‚Üí
    78‚Üí  passing_criteria:
    79‚Üí    - Score >= 4 on all claims
    80‚Üí    - Zero untraced claims
    81‚Üí    - Metrics exact match
    82‚Üí```
    83‚Üí
    84‚Üí### Automated Checks (Future)
    85‚Üí- [ ] Metric extraction and comparison
    86‚Üí- [ ] Company/year validation
    87‚Üí- [ ] Skill claim verification
    88‚Üí
    89‚Üí---
    90‚Üí
    91‚Üí## Dimension 2: Role Relevance
    92‚Üí
    93‚Üí**Definition:** Generated content emphasizes achievements relevant to the target role.
    94‚Üí
    95‚Üí### Rubric
    96‚Üí
    97‚Üí| Score | Criteria | Example |
    98‚Üí|-------|----------|---------|
    99‚Üí| 5 | Perfectly tailored, obvious fit | Platform PM variant highlights infrastructure work |
   100‚Üí| 4 | Clearly relevant, minor gaps | Most content relevant, some generic sections |
   101‚Üí| 3 | Partially relevant | Mix of relevant and irrelevant achievements |
   102‚Üí| 2 | Mostly generic | Same as base with minor tweaks |
   103‚Üí| 1 | Wrong emphasis | Highlights irrelevant experience |
   104‚Üí| 0 | Completely misaligned | Crypto variant for non-crypto role |
   105‚Üí
   106‚Üí### Evaluation Method
   107‚Üí
   108‚Üí```yaml
   109‚Üírelevance_check:
   110‚Üí  process:
   111‚Üí    1. Extract key requirements from target job description
   112‚Üí    2. Map requirements to knowledge base themes/skills
   113‚Üí    3. Check if variant emphasizes matching achievements
   114‚Üí    4. Verify case study ranking reflects relevance
   115‚Üí
   116‚Üí  passing_criteria:
   117‚Üí    - Score >= 4
   118‚Üí    - Top 3 case studies match role requirements
   119‚Üí    - Hero/about customized for role
   120‚Üí```
   121‚Üí
   122‚Üí### Scoring Template
   123‚Üí
   124‚Üí```yaml
   125‚Üívariant: stripe-platform-pm
   126‚Üítarget_requirements:
   127‚Üí  - API infrastructure
   128‚Üí  - Revenue/growth metrics
   129‚Üí  - B2B platform experience
   130‚Üí  - Scale/performance
   131‚Üí
   132‚Üírelevance_scores:
   133‚Üí  hero_section: 4/5        # Mentions platform, APIs
   134‚Üí  about_section: 5/5       # Emphasizes infrastructure background
   135‚Üí  case_study_ranking:
   136‚Üí    - ankr-rpc: relevant   # APIs, growth ‚úì
   137‚Üí    - protocol-integration: relevant  # Platform scale ‚úì
   138‚Üí    - eth-staking: partial # Infra yes, crypto specific
   139‚Üí  overall: 4.3/5
   140‚Üí```
   141‚Üí
   142‚Üí---
   143‚Üí
   144‚Üí## Dimension 3: Tone & Voice
   145‚Üí
   146‚Üí**Definition:** Content sounds professional, authentic, and appropriate for context.
   147‚Üí
   148‚Üí### Rubric
   149‚Üí
   150‚Üí| Score | Criteria | Example |
   151‚Üí|-------|----------|---------|
   152‚Üí| 5 | Authentic voice, professional, confident | Natural, sounds like the candidate |
   153‚Üí| 4 | Professional, slightly generic | Good but could be anyone |
   154‚Üí| 3 | Acceptable but bland | Reads like template |
   155‚Üí| 2 | Awkward or overly formal | Stilted language |
   156‚Üí| 1 | Sycophantic or desperate | "I would be honored to..." |
   157‚Üí| 0 | Inappropriate or unprofessional | Casual, errors, wrong register |
   158‚Üí
   159‚Üí### Anti-Patterns to Check
   160‚Üí
   161‚Üí| Anti-Pattern | Example | Why It's Bad |
   162‚Üí|--------------|---------|--------------|
   163‚Üí| Sycophancy | "Your amazing company..." | Inauthentic, obvious |
   164‚Üí| Keyword stuffing | "Agile Scrum Kubernetes cloud native..." | Gaming, not substance |
   165‚Üí| Over-humility | "I was lucky to..." | Undermines achievements |
   166‚Üí| Grandiosity | "Revolutionary transformation..." | Inflated, unbelievable |
   167‚Üí| Generic praise | "Industry-leading organization..." | Empty, meaningless |
   168‚Üí
   169‚Üí### Evaluation Method
   170‚Üí
   171‚Üí```yaml
   172‚Üítone_check:
   173‚Üí  process:
   174‚Üí    1. Read generated content aloud
   175‚Üí    2. Check against anti-pattern list
   176‚Üí    3. Verify consistent voice throughout
   177‚Üí    4. Compare to base portfolio voice
   178‚Üí
   179‚Üí  passing_criteria:
   180‚Üí    - Score >= 4
   181‚Üí    - Zero sycophancy detected
   182‚Üí    - No keyword stuffing
   183‚Üí    - Voice consistent with base
   184‚Üí```
   185‚Üí
   186‚Üí---
   187‚Üí
   188‚Üí## Dimension 4: Safety & Ethics
   189‚Üí
   190‚Üí**Definition:** Content is honest, ethical, and wouldn't cause harm if discovered.
   191‚Üí
   192‚Üí### Rubric
   193‚Üí
   194‚Üí| Score | Criteria | Example |
   195‚Üí|-------|----------|---------|
   196‚Üí| 5 | Completely defensible | Every claim can be explained in interview |
   197‚Üí| 4 | Defensible with context | Minor phrasing that needs explanation |
   198‚Üí| 3 | Borderline | Some claims stretch the truth |
   199‚Üí| 2 | Questionable | Would be embarrassing if challenged |
   200‚Üí| 1 | Deceptive | Intentionally misleading |
   201‚Üí| 0 | Fraudulent | Fabricated credentials/achievements |
   202‚Üí
   203‚Üí### Safety Checks
   204‚Üí
   205‚Üí| Check | Pass Criteria |
   206‚Üí|-------|---------------|
   207‚Üí| Hallucination | No invented achievements |
   208‚Üí| Metric inflation | Numbers exactly match source |
   209‚Üí| Title accuracy | Roles match actual positions held |
   210‚Üí| Timeline accuracy | Dates/periods correct |
   211‚Üí| Attribution | Work attributed to correct company |
   212‚Üí| Privacy | No confidential information exposed |
   213‚Üí
   214‚Üí### The "Interview Test"
   215‚Üí
   216‚Üí> Would you be comfortable if the interviewer asked you to elaborate on any claim?
   217‚Üí
   218‚Üí```yaml
   219‚Üísafety_check:
   220‚Üí  process:
   221‚Üí    1. For each major claim, ask "Can I defend this?"
   222‚Üí    2. Check if metrics are exact or rounded up
   223‚Üí    3. Verify no confidential information leaked
   224‚Üí    4. Ensure no claims about future intentions
   225‚Üí
   226‚Üí  passing_criteria:
   227‚Üí    - Score >= 5 (no tolerance for safety issues)
   228‚Üí    - All claims pass interview test
   229‚Üí    - Zero confidential information
   230‚Üí```
   231‚Üí
   232‚Üí---
   233‚Üí
   234‚Üí## Evaluation Process
   235‚Üí
   236‚Üí### Per-Variant Evaluation

 `./content/blog/2024-12-22-portfolio-retrospective.md`
```
     1‚Üí---
     2‚Üítitle: "Building a Portfolio That Proves Itself"
     3‚Üídate: "2024-12-22"
     4‚Üíexcerpt: "The best portfolio isn't one that looks good‚Äîit's one where every claim traces to proof. Here's what I learned building a system that verifies itself."
     5‚Üítags: ["Career", "AI", "Portfolio", "Capstone", "Web3"]
     6‚Üíthumbnail: null
     7‚Üí---
     8‚Üí
     9‚ÜíFound myself between roles. Sat with the question everyone asks: *what's next?*
    10‚Üí
    11‚ÜíI knew two things: I wanted to stay at the intersection of Web3 and AI, and I needed a better way to present my work. The standard resume wasn't cutting it. LinkedIn felt like shouting into the void.
    12‚Üí
    13‚ÜíSo I started building. Three months later, I had something unexpected: not just a portfolio, but a system that proves its own claims.
    14‚Üí
    15‚Üí## The Problem
    16‚Üí
    17‚ÜíGeneric portfolios don't convert. Every product manager has "drove growth" and "led cross-functional teams" on their resume. Metrics help, but metrics without sources feel hollow. How do you know those numbers are real?
    18‚Üí
    19‚ÜíAnd here's the real problem: when you're applying for multiple roles, you need different emphasis. The infrastructure PM variant isn't the Web3 PM variant isn't the developer tools PM variant. Maintaining multiple versions by hand is a nightmare.
    20‚Üí
    21‚ÜíI wanted something that could generate targeted variants while ensuring every claim was defensible.
    22‚Üí
    23‚Üí## What I Built
    24‚Üí
    25‚ÜíThe system has four layers:
    26‚Üí
    27‚Üí**Knowledge Base**: Every achievement lives in structured YAML, using STAR format (Situation, Task, Action, Result). Each metric traces to a source. No hallucination possible‚Äîthe AI can only surface what's already documented.
    28‚Üí
    29‚Üí**Variant Engine**: Takes a job description, matches it against my knowledge base, scores relevance, and generates a customized portfolio. Different stats, different case study ordering, same underlying facts.
    30‚Üí
    31‚Üí**Quality Pipeline**: This is where it gets interesting. Every variant runs through:
    32‚Üí- **Eval**: Extracts claims, finds candidate sources, verifies each metric
    33‚Üí- **Red Team**: Scans for sycophantic language, unverified metrics, cross-variant contamination, confidential leaks
    34‚Üí
    35‚Üí**Skills Ecosystem**: Nine Claude Code skills that codify the workflow. The AI doesn't freelance‚Äîit follows documented patterns with human approval gates.
    36‚Üí
    37‚Üí## The Numbers
    38‚Üí
    39‚ÜíWhat three months of building produced:
    40‚Üí
    41‚Üí| Metric | Value |
    42‚Üí|--------|-------|
    43‚Üí| CSS Variables | 124 (full design system) |
    44‚Üí| Initial Bundle | 195KB gzip (59% reduction from 480KB) |
    45‚Üí| Claude Code Skills | 9 (knowledge ‚Üí content ‚Üí variants) |
    46‚Üí| Job-Specific Variants | 9 active |
    47‚Üí| Claims Per Variant | ~6 (100% traceable) |
    48‚Üí| Red Team Checks | 8 automated gates |
    49‚Üí| Tests | 211 passing |
    50‚Üí

<system-reminder>

    41‚Üí

    43‚Üí

    45‚Üí- Bootstrapping solo with limited resources
    46‚Üí- Multiple chains needed (Ethereum, Cosmos ecosystem)
    47‚Üí- Sub-second latency or it's worthless‚Äîalerts after the fact are just news
    48‚Üí- Developer SDK simple enough for quick integration
    49‚Üí

## KEY INSIGHTS ABOUT THE PROJECT

1. **Quality-First Architecture**: The portfolio isn't just a website‚Äîit's a quality pipeline. Every claim traces to a knowledge base, gets evaluated, and passes red-team checks before deployment.

2. **AI-Powered Automation**: 10 Claude Code skills codify the workflow (content generation, editing, ingestion, evaluation, red-teaming).

3. **Personalization Engine**: Universal CV system generates job-specific variants from a single knowledge base, maintaining factual consistency while optimizing for role fit.

4. **Governance**: Comprehensive documentation of AI agent rules, design system constraints, and validation workflows to maintain consistency.

5. **Three-Month Build**: The blog post (2024-12-22) reveals this entire system was built in ~3 months with remarkable scope: 124 CSS variables, 195KB bundle (59% reduction), 9 variants, 211 tests.

All files are well-organized and serve clear purposes in supporting a production-grade portfolio with AI-assisted personalization and quality assurance.

     1‚Üí---
     2‚Üítitle: "Building a Portfolio That Proves Itself"
     3‚Üídate: "2024-12-22"
     4‚Üíexcerpt: "The best portfolio isn't one that looks good‚Äîit's one where every claim traces to proof. Here's what I learned building a system that verifies itself."
     5‚Üítags: ["Career", "AI", "Portfolio", "Capstone", "Web3"]
     6‚Üíthumbnail: null
     7‚Üí---
     8‚Üí
     9‚ÜíFound myself between roles. Sat with the question everyone asks: *what's next?*
    10‚Üí
    11‚ÜíI knew two things: I wanted to stay at the intersection of Web3 and AI, and I needed a better way to present my work. The standard resume wasn't cutting it. LinkedIn felt like shouting into the void.
    12‚Üí
    13‚ÜíSo I started building. Three months later, I had something unexpected: not just a portfolio, but a system that proves its own claims.
    14‚Üí
    15‚Üí## The Problem
    16‚Üí
    17‚ÜíGeneric portfolios don't convert. Every product manager has "drove growth" and "led cross-functional teams" on their resume. Metrics help, but metrics without sources feel hollow. How do you know those numbers are real?
    18‚Üí
    19‚ÜíAnd here's the real problem: when you're applying for multiple roles, you need different emphasis. The infrastructure PM variant isn't the Web3 PM variant isn't the developer tools PM variant. Maintaining multiple versions by hand is a nightmare.
    20‚Üí
    21‚ÜíI wanted something that could generate targeted variants while ensuring every claim was defensible.
    22‚Üí
    23‚Üí## What I Built
    24‚Üí
    25‚ÜíThe system has four layers:
    26‚Üí
    27‚Üí**Knowledge Base**: Every achievement lives in structured YAML, using STAR format (Situation, Task, Action, Result). Each metric traces to a source. No hallucination possible‚Äîthe AI can only surface what's already documented.
    28‚Üí
    29‚Üí**Variant Engine**: Takes a job description, matches it against my knowledge base, scores relevance, and generates a customized portfolio. Different stats, different case study ordering, same underlying facts.
    30‚Üí
    31‚Üí**Quality Pipeline**: This is where it gets interesting. Every variant runs through:
    32‚Üí- **Eval**: Extracts claims, finds candidate sources, verifies each metric
    33‚Üí- **Red Team**: Scans for sycophantic language, unverified metrics, cross-variant contamination, confidential leaks
    34‚Üí
    35‚Üí**Skills Ecosystem**: Nine Claude Code skills that codify the workflow. The AI doesn't freelance‚Äîit follows documented patterns with human approval gates.
    36‚Üí
    37‚Üí## The Numbers
    38‚Üí
    39‚ÜíWhat three months of building produced:
    40‚Üí
    41‚Üí| Metric | Value |
    42‚Üí|--------|-------|
    43‚Üí| CSS Variables | 124 (full design system) |
    44‚Üí| Initial Bundle | 195KB gzip (59% reduction from 480KB) |
    45‚Üí| Claude Code Skills | 9 (knowledge ‚Üí content ‚Üí variants) |
    46‚Üí| Job-Specific Variants | 9 active |
    47‚Üí| Claims Per Variant | ~6 (100% traceable) |
    48‚Üí| Red Team Checks | 8 automated gates |
    49‚Üí| Tests | 211 passing |
    50‚Üí
    51‚Üí## What I Learned
    52‚Üí
    53‚Üí### Tier 1: Fundamental Shifts
    54‚Üí
    55‚Üí**Schema is law.** Zod validates everything. A typo in a YAML field doesn't silently fail‚Äîit blocks the build. Content quality compounds when you enforce it at the source.
    56‚Üí
    57‚Üí**Voice is brand.** I created a separate skill just for writing style. Not embedded in generators‚Äîexplicit and mandatory. Same facts rendered in consistent voice across every variant, email, and document.
    58‚Üí
    59‚Üí**Verification beats trust.** Every metric in a variant traces to a knowledge base file. If the source changes, the variant fails eval. You can't accidentally ship unverified claims.
    60‚Üí
    61‚Üí### Tier 2: Architectural Decisions
    62‚Üí
    63‚Üí**YAML for humans, JSON for machines.** Variants live in YAML (human-reviewable), sync to JSON (runtime artifact). One canonical source, derived outputs. No drift.
    64‚Üí
    65‚Üí**Code splitting saved 59%.** The bundle hit 480KB and I stopped everything to fix it. Lazy-loaded routes, vendor chunking, component-level splitting. Target was under 200KB‚Äîhit 195KB.
    66‚Üí
    67‚Üí**CSS variables over CSS-in-JS.** Theme switching is instant‚Äîno React re-render needed. 124 variables covering color, spacing, layout, effects. Dark and light mode parity without JavaScript overhead.
    68‚Üí
    69‚Üí### Tier 3: Process Insights
    70‚Üí
    71‚Üí**Pause between phases.** The variant skill has explicit approval gates: show content ‚Üí user approves ‚Üí run eval ‚Üí user reviews ‚Üí red team ‚Üí user approves ‚Üí ship. No autonomous hallucination.
    72‚Üí
    73‚Üí**Existing connections are gold.** When generating the Galaxy variant, I discovered they were already an Anchorage client (from ETH staking work). Lead with what you've already proven.
    74‚Üí
    75‚Üí**Stats should be punchy.** "8+" beats "approximately eight." "Zero" beats "no instances of." "40%" beats "significant improvement." Every stat verifiable, every stat memorable.
    76‚Üí
    77‚Üí### Tier 4: Meta Learnings
    78‚Üí
    79‚Üí**ADHD patterns are predictable.** I built a skill that diagnoses drift: tooling rabbit holes, perfect setup syndrome, research loops, scope creep. The system catches me when I'm avoiding the real work.
    80‚Üí
    81‚Üí**Multi-perspective briefings work.** Sprint sync outputs from four angles: PM (priorities), Designer (system health), Architect (dependencies), Engineer (recent changes). Different lenses, same project.
    82‚Üí
    83‚Üí**The last 8% is applying.** The portfolio is 92% done. The remaining 8% isn't code‚Äîit's hitting submit on applications. Portfolio perfection is a form of procrastination.
    84‚Üí
    85‚Üí## The Pipeline in Practice
    86‚Üí
    87‚ÜíHere's what generating a variant actually looks like:
    88‚Üí
    89‚Üí```bash
    90‚Üí# Phase 1: Job analysis
    91‚Üí# Extract requirements, generate slug, check for existing variants
    92‚Üí
    93‚Üí# Phase 2: Knowledge base query
    94‚Üínpm run cv-knowledge-query -- --theme "institutional-crypto"
    95‚Üí
    96‚Üí# Phase 3: Content generation (with writing style skill)
    97‚Üí# Generate hero, about, stats‚Äîall from verified sources
    98‚Üí
    99‚Üí# Phase 4: Sync and validate
   100‚Üínpm run variants:sync -- --slug microsoft-senior-pm
   101‚Üí
   102‚Üí# Phase 5: Evaluate claims
   103‚Üínpm run eval:variant -- --slug microsoft-senior-pm
   104‚Üí# Output: 6/6 claims verified
   105‚Üí
   106‚Üí# Phase 6: Red team
   107‚Üínpm run redteam:variant -- --slug microsoft-senior-pm
   108‚Üí# Output: 0 FAIL, 0 WARN
   109‚Üí
   110‚Üí# Phase 7: Visual review
   111‚Üíopen "http://localhost:5173/microsoft/senior-pm"
   112‚Üí```
   113‚Üí
   114‚ÜíThe whole flow takes about 15 minutes. Most of that is human review, not generation.
   115‚Üí
   116‚Üí## Why This Matters
   117‚Üí
   118‚ÜíMost AI-generated content has a trust problem. It sounds plausible but might be fabricated. For a portfolio‚Äîwhere your professional reputation is on the line‚Äîthat's unacceptable.
   119‚Üí
   120‚ÜíThis system inverts the approach:
   121‚Üí1. Start with verified source data
   122‚Üí2. Constrain generation to that data
   123‚Üí3. Evaluate every claim against sources
   124‚Üí4. Red-team for tone and accuracy issues
   125‚Üí5. Require human approval at each gate
   126‚Üí
   127‚ÜíThe AI assists with targeting and presentation. The facts come from documented achievements.
   128‚Üí
   129‚Üí## What's Next
   130‚Üí
   131‚ÜíThe portfolio is live. The capstone is submitted. But the work continues:
   132‚Üí
   133‚Üí- **More variants**: Galaxy, Microsoft, Coinbase, Gensyn all in active rotation
   134‚Üí- **Case studies**: Documenting the portfolio build itself, the Universal CV pipeline, the AI-assisted job search
   135‚Üí- **Open source**: Planning to release the variant generation system once it's battle-tested
   136‚Üí
   137‚Üí## The Real Lesson
   138‚Üí
   139‚ÜíCareer transitions create space. This one let me build something I wouldn't have built otherwise‚Äîa portfolio that doesn't just show my work, but demonstrates the rigor I bring to shipping.
   140‚Üí
   141‚ÜíEvery claim traceable. Every variant verified. Every stat defensible in an interview.

The problem: static resumes don't adapt. You need different emphasis for infrastructure PM vs. developer tools PM vs. Web3 PM. Maintaining multiple versions by hand is a nightmare. And AI-generated content? Sounds good until someone asks where those metrics came from.

```md
# LinkedIn Article

**Title**: I Built a Portfolio That Proves Itself

---

Found myself between roles a few months ago. Sat with the question everyone asks: what's next?

I knew two things. I wanted to stay at the intersection of Web3 and AI. And I needed a better way to present my work. The standard resume wasn't cutting it. LinkedIn felt like shouting into the void.

So I started building. Three months later, I had something unexpected: not just a portfolio, but a system that verifies its own claims.

## The Problem with Portfolios

Every product manager has "drove growth" and "led cross-functional teams" on their resume. Metrics help, but metrics without sources feel hollow. How do you know those numbers are real?

Here's the deeper problem: when you're applying for multiple roles, you need different emphasis. The infrastructure PM pitch isn't the Web3 PM pitch isn't the developer tools PM pitch. Maintaining multiple versions by hand is a nightmare. You either send generic content or burn hours on customization.

AI-generated content seems like the answer‚Äîuntil someone asks where those metrics came from. Most AI portfolios have a trust problem. They sound plausible but might be fabricated.

I wanted something that could generate targeted variants while ensuring every claim was defensible in an interview.

## What I Built

The system has four layers.

**Knowledge Base**: Every achievement lives in structured YAML using STAR format. Each metric traces to a source document. No hallucination possible‚Äîthe AI can only surface what's already documented.

**Variant Engine**: Takes a job description, matches it against my knowledge base, scores relevance, and generates a customized portfolio. Different stats, different case study ordering, same underlying facts.

**Quality Pipeline**: Every variant runs through evaluation (extracting claims, finding sources, verifying each metric) and red-teaming (scanning for sycophantic language, unverified metrics, confidential leaks). Nothing ships without passing both gates.

**Skills Ecosystem**: Nine Claude Code skills that codify the workflow. The AI doesn't freelance‚Äîit follows documented patterns with human approval at each step.

## Three Learnings Worth Sharing

Building this system crystallized insights from years of shipping infrastructure products.

**Distribution beats product.** At my previous startup, we spent months building the best on-chain alerting product. Competitors with worse products still won. The difference? We eventually launched as the default alerting provider for an entire blockchain ecosystem. One partnership delivered more than a hundred marketing campaigns could. The best product doesn't win‚Äîthe best-distributed product does.

**Customer isn't always user.** At Ankr, we spent eight months chasing individual developers. Made $130K ARR. Then we shifted focus to blockchain protocols as customers instead of developers. Same product, different buyer. Revenue increased 15x in six months. Sometimes the unit economics problem isn't your product‚Äîit's who you're optimizing for.

**Trust is the moat.** In institutional crypto, nobody cares about the best APY. They care about auditability, compliance, and defensibility. At Microsoft, we shipped a blockchain royalty system for 2.7 billion Xbox consumers not because it was the fastest‚Äîbecause it was the most defensible. This portfolio applies the same principle: every claim traces to a source. Every stat survives scrutiny.

## The Numbers

What three months of building produced:

- 124 CSS variables defining a complete design system
- 195KB initial bundle (reduced 59% from 480KB)
- 9 job-specific variants in active rotation
- 211 passing tests across 10 test suites
- 8 automated red-team checks per variant
- 100% claim traceability to source documentation

The whole variant generation flow takes about 15 minutes. Most of that is human review, not generation.

## Why This Approach Matters

Most AI-generated content requires you to trust the output. For a portfolio‚Äîwhere your professional reputation is on the line‚Äîthat's unacceptable.

This system inverts the approach. Start with verified source data. Constrain generation to that data. Evaluate every claim against sources. Red-team for tone and accuracy issues. Require human approval at each gate.

The AI assists with targeting and presentation. The facts come from documented achievements.

## What's Next

The portfolio is live at edgeoftrust.com. Nine variants covering Bloomberg, Coinbase, Galaxy, Meta, Microsoft, and more‚Äîeach tailored to the role while maintaining factual consistency.

After years building infrastructure at Microsoft (blockchain royalties for Xbox), Ankr (RPC infrastructure serving millions of requests), and Anchorage Digital (institutional crypto custody), I'm exploring what's next.

If you're building in Web3, AI infrastructure, or institutional crypto, I'd love to connect. Reach out directly or explore the portfolio to see the system in action.

---

*The best portfolio isn't one that looks good‚Äîit's one where every claim traces to proof.*

---

**Word count**: ~780
**Suggested tags**: Product Management, AI, Web3, Career Development, Portfolio

```
```
File created successfully at: /Users/dfotesco/Portfolio/portfolio/content/social/linkedin-article.md
```
</details></tool-use>

# YouTube Video Transcript

**Title**: I Built a Portfolio That Proves Itself (Universal CV Engine)
**Duration**: ~4 minutes

---

## INTRO (0:00 - 0:30)

I built a portfolio that generates itself. One knowledge base, nine job-specific variants, zero hallucinations.

Found myself between roles a few months ago. The standard resume wasn't cutting it. Maintaining multiple versions by hand was a nightmare. And AI-generated content? Sounds great until someone asks where those metrics came from.

So I built something different. Let me show you how it works.

---

## THE PROBLEM (0:30 - 1:15)

Here's the problem with portfolios in 2025.

Every product manager has "drove growth" and "led cross-functional teams" on their resume. Metrics help, but metrics without sources feel hollow.

When you're applying for multiple roles, you need different emphasis. The infrastructure PM pitch isn't the Web3 PM pitch. The developer tools PM pitch is different again. Customizing for each role takes hours. Most people either send generic content or burn out.

AI-generated content seems like the answer‚Äîuntil you realize most of it hallucinates. It sounds plausible, but the numbers might be made up. For a portfolio where your professional reputation is on the line, that's unacceptable.

I wanted something that could target each role while keeping every claim defensible in an interview.

---

## THE BUILD (1:15 - 2:45)

The Universal CV Engine has four layers.

First, the knowledge base. Every achievement I've ever shipped lives in structured files. Each metric traces to a source document. No hallucination possible‚Äîthe AI can only surface what's already documented.

Second, the variant engine. Give it a job description, and it matches against my knowledge base, scores relevance, and generates a customized portfolio. Different stats, different case study ordering, same underlying facts.

Third, the quality pipeline. This is where it gets interesting. Every variant runs through an evaluation pass‚Äîextracting claims, finding sources, verifying each metric. Then red-teaming‚Äîscanning for sycophantic language, unverified stats, confidential leaks. Nothing ships without passing both gates.

Fourth, the skills ecosystem. Nine automation skills that codify the whole workflow. The AI doesn't freelance. It follows documented patterns with human approval at each step.

*[VISUAL: Show edgeoftrust.com with different variant URLs]*

Here's what it looks like in practice. Same portfolio, different variants. Bloomberg Technical PM. Coinbase Product Manager. Galaxy. Meta. Microsoft. Each one tailored to the role, each one traceable to the same source of truth.

---

## TOP 3 LEARNINGS (2:45 - 3:30)

Building this crystallized three insights from years of shipping products.

**One: Distribution beats product.** At my previous startup, we built the best product. Competitors with worse products still won. The difference was distribution. One ecosystem partnership delivered more than a hundred marketing campaigns.

**Two: Customer isn't always user.** At Ankr, we chased developers for eight months. Made $130K ARR. Shifted to protocols as customers instead‚Äîsame product, different buyer. Revenue increased 15x. Sometimes the unit economics problem isn't your product. It's who you're optimizing for.

**Three: Trust is the moat.** In institutional crypto, nobody cares about the best APY. They care about auditability. This portfolio applies the same principle‚Äîevery claim traces to a source. Every stat survives scrutiny.

---

## CTA (3:30 - 4:00)

The portfolio is live at edgeoftrust.com. Nine variants, 211 passing tests, 100% claim traceability.

After years building infrastructure at Microsoft, Ankr, and Anchorage Digital, I'm exploring what's next. If you're building in Web3, AI infrastructure, or institutional crypto‚Äîlink in the description, let's connect.

If you found this useful, subscribe. I'm thinking about open-sourcing the variant generation system. Let me know in the comments if that would be helpful.

---

**Word count**: ~650 (~4 min read/narration)

**Suggested visuals**:
- 0:00-0:30: Talking head or title card
- 0:30-1:15: Split screen with resume examples
- 1:15-2:45: Screen recording of edgeoftrust.com
- 2:45-3:30: Text overlays for each learning
- 3:30-4:00: CTA card with URL

**Description template**:
\```
I built a portfolio system that generates job-specific variants while ensuring every claim is traceable and defensible.

üîó Portfolio: https://edgeoftrust.com
üîó LinkedIn: [your LinkedIn]
üîó Twitter/X: [your X handle]

The Universal CV Engine:

_**Agent (claude-opus-4-5-20251101)**_

Here's the LinkedIn post:

---

Found myself between roles a few months ago. Instead of mass-applying, I built something.

The problem: static resumes don't adapt. You need different emphasis for infrastructure PM vs. developer tools PM vs. Web3 PM. Maintaining multiple versions by hand is a nightmare. And AI-generated content? Sounds good until someone asks where those metrics came from.

So I built a Universal CV Engine. One knowledge base stores every achievement with traceable sources. The system generates targeted variants for each role while ensuring every claim is defensible. Red team checks catch sycophantic language and unverified metrics before anything ships.

Three months later: 9 job-specific variants, 211 passing tests, every stat traceable to source documentation. The portfolio doesn't just show my work‚Äîit demonstrates the rigor I bring to shipping.

Check it out: edgeoftrust.com

After years building infrastructure at Microsoft, Ankr, and Anchorage Digital, I'm exploring what's next. If you're building in Web3, AI infrastructure, or institutional crypto‚Äîlet's talk.

---

**~1,050 characters** | Optional hashtags: #ProductManagement #Web3 #AI #CareerTransition #OpenToWork

Want me to adjust the tone, length, or emphasis?
